1. A 45-year-old man presents with progressive facial flushing, episodic palpitations, and intermittent diarrhea over the past six months. He also complains of a persistent central chest pain and mild dyspnea on exertion. His medical history is unremarkable, and he is a non-smoker with no occupational exposures. Physical examination reveals mild facial erythema and decreased breath sounds in the upper anterior chest. A chest CT scan demonstrates a 4.5 cm well-circumscribed mass in the anterior mediastinum, closely related to the thymus gland. Laboratory evaluation shows elevated serum serotonin and urinary 5-HIAA levels, raising suspicion for a neuroendocrine tumor. A CT-guided biopsy confirms a low-grade thymic neuroendocrine tumor. He is scheduled for multidisciplinary evaluation with thoracic surgery and oncology to discuss options for surgical resection and adjunctive therapies.
